I think he will terminate in the summer or fall, but definitely before January 1, 2020. 1) From “Special Counsel Investigations: History, Authority, Appointment and Removal,” Updated March 13, 2019 https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R44857.pdf “Termination of Independent Counsel Inquiries The inquiry led by the independent counsel under the statute could be terminated under two methods. First, the statute directed that the office of the independent counsel would terminate upon notification by the independent counsel to the Attorney General that the investigation and any subsequent prosecutions had been completed.63 Second, the statute permitted the special division of the court—by its own choice or by the recommendation of the Attorney General—to terminate the office at any time if the investigation had been completed or sufficiently completed, allowing DOJ to formally complete the inquiry under its own processes.64 In either case, the independent counsel was required to submit a report to the special division of the court detailing the work completed.65 The report was required to include “a description of the work of the independent counsel, including the disposition of all cases brought.” 66” 2) The Mueller Report - https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/5955379/Redacted-Mueller-Report.pdf  Mueller did not terminate in this document (see page 11…)

First regarding the position of removal via force vs. conclusion of service. Removal via force would certainly cause cause the case to wind up at the feet of the US Supreme Court, & given the fact that the last occurrence of such (Morrison v. Olson) ruled in favor of the appointment, I would expect such a vote to go the same way if presented again. However, none of the current justices were on the court at the time, so there is a distinctly non-zero chance the decision would flip. As it pertains to conclusion of service, it's worth noting that the posed question asks about Mueller as special counsel generally, leaving open the possibility that additional investigations are opened, thus prolonging his period of service. I would place odds of this extending time as special counsel as slim, though putting a number on this seems arbitrary given lack of knowledge on how this would take place. Looking at the more pure-statistical viewpoint, the average length of special/independent counsel inquiry is reported as 1,154 days (911 excluding the longest outlier and a median of 668 days. Prodding at this data gives a pretty rough (and arguably inconclusive) return that > 80% of investigations conclude prior to eclipsing ~1,200 days. This is the best bit of information I have as a basis, so I'll use this as my anchor. On top of this I'll bring in the SSA's actuarial life tables which state that you have roughly a 3.3% chance of dying at the age of 74 and 3.6% at 75 (Mueller will turn 75 in August). So I'll place the arbitrated value here at 2.8% by January 1st 2020 (Let's call it 3%).

Whitaker, the acting attorney general, announced on Monday that the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, is wrapping up his investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential campaign and whether the Trump campaign cooperated with Moscow’s operation. “The investigation is, I think, close to being completed, and I hope that we can get the report from Director Mueller as soon as possible,” Mr. Whitaker said. His impromptu remark, at the end of a news conference about an unrelated case, was a highly unusual confirmation of the state of the special counsel’s investigation. Justice Department policy ordinarily prohibits public comment on open criminal inquiries, and Mr. Mueller has refused to publicly discuss the investigation since he was appointed in May 2017 to oversee it. Mr. Whitaker, who is considered intensely loyal to President Trump, said that he had been “fully briefed on the investigation” and that he looked forward to Mr. Mueller delivering a report. Mr. Whitaker’s comments appeared to take even Justice Department officials by surprise. As soon as he described the special counsel’s work as nearly over, a spokeswoman shut down the news conference, declaring hastily: “That’s all the time for today. Thank you so much.” It was unclear whether Mr. Whitaker had discussed his comments with Mr. Mueller beforehand, or if he was speaking off the cuff. A spokesman for Mr. Mueller, Peter Carr, declined to comment. Prosecutors typically shy away from discussing the progress of investigations to avoid unfairly framing public expectations, partly because new evidence could unexpectedly arise. Mr. Whitaker acknowledged that tradition before giving his assessment of Mr. Mueller’s progress. “I am really not going to talk about an open and ongoing investigation,” he said. Mr. Whitaker’s remarks “may be harmless,” said Barbara McQuade, a former United States attorney who now teaches law at the University of Michigan. Nonetheless, she said, “There isn’t any advantage in announcing you are close to the end. You might think that you are close, and then your very last witness leads you to five new witnesses.”

I see three ways Mueller will cease to be Special Counsel: he dies or suffers debilitating illness or injury (so he cannot continue); he voluntarily leaves the position; or, he involuntarily leaves the position. There are (at least) two ways he could leave voluntarily: He will have completed the assignment, issued the report and initiated any needed legal action; or, he will choose to leave with the job unfinished, for unknown reasons (frustration, coercion by foreign agents or organized crime, etc). There are several ways he could leave involuntarily: the President could order his dismissal; the Deputy AG or AG could order his dismissal; or, he could have some public misstep where he breaks a law (or appears to) and is forced out by Congress, US SC, or the like.
I will start with voluntary alternatives, which I think have the highest chance. Since he has been at the job for two years without finishing, the expected completion duration is another 2 years (see Lindy rule in Taleb's Skin in the Game), although I think the probabilities are front loaded to some degree. I think there's a 55% chance he will have completed his work within the next year, and leave voluntarily. The chances of leaving voluntarily for other reasons strike me as vanishingly small and don't affect my estimate.
According to actuarial tables, he has about a 3.5% chance of dying in the next year (as a 74-75 year old man), and I will round up to 5% allowing for some grave injury or illness.  This puts my base estimate at about 60% (granted that straight addition of 55+5 isn't strictly correct).
What strikes me as far less certain is the chance he could be forced to leave by the President or others. This could happen, theoretically, but I have a hard time imagining anyone taking that step for the President, no matter how bullet-proof they see themselves. I think it's very unlikely he will be forced out.
I'm settling on 60% chance as a first estimate, and I qualify that by saying it will be because he will have completed his assignment to his satisfaction, more likely to be closer to the end of the year, rather than earlier.

While several possibilities exist as to why Mueller may cease to be Special Counsel before January 1, 2020, their cumulative probability is still fairly low. I put the possibilities into 3 large buckets (resignation, dismissal, other).  Although there are many reasons for resignation, the two I assume are of greatest probability are (1) he completes his work and (2) he gets fed up or feels he can no longer perform the job and decides to quit before the job is done.  Many people assume that Mueller will issue a final report soon and that will end his tenure. While possible, this seems to me unlikey given what the Special Proscutor's office actually has to do after the dust settles and the press walks away. Two previous special counsel's, let alone Ken Starr's investigation as Independent Counsel (which started in 1994), have taken several years on average to complete (Pat Fitzgerald's Plame investigation took 3 years; Danforth's Waco investigation to 7 years). Mueller's investigation only started in May 2017, therefore it seems unlikely he would complete his investigation and prosecutions (especially if trials are required) before January 2020. More likely is that he will issue some report on the investigation, but will continue to prosecute individuals who do not plea--it's not just about his Trump findings. If so, this could take months or years. Indeed, we haven't heard a peep from Mueller about the possibility of charges against any of Trump's inner circle (kids, in-laws) other than Manafort (on other charges, not collusion)  or the president himself. If any of the inner circle expect to be charged we will hear about that as it will get leaked (not by Mueller's team, but by the targets). Even if they eventually plead, the process around pleading and sentencing will take a long time and I don't think we are anywhere near that, even with nearly a year to go. While he could theoretically resign before all prosecutions are complete and leave those to a deputy, it is not yet clear whether he would be so inclined and while the press and American public might move on from monitoring bit player trials, Mueller's team would still be there prosecuting them. So unless everyone indicted or to be indicted pleads guilty, some work will likely continue into 2020. I therefore only give an pre-2020 resignation date at no more than 15%. On  (2), he seems to have weathered the political storm sufficiently to avoid having to resign. Even if a new AG comes in and puts pressure on him to finish the job quickly, it seems unlikely he would succumb to pressure to quit or feel ineffective given he is presumably far enough long in the investigation to at least report out findings/conclusions about the president and his inner circle.  He could also be fired by the acting or new Attorney General. Such a move, however, would come with great political risk that other Republicans would balk at and, as such, would try to convince Trump to avoid having the AG do that for fear of political backlash. if Mueller starts to close the net on the inner circle, we may hear more clamoring to fire him, but it would be political suicide to do so then. At this point, it seems too late to fire him and it would look like a hatchet job leading to potential grounds for impeachment. I put this at no more than 5%.  There could be some non-political or work-related reason for his departure (health, family issues, etc.) but those seem fairly remote and I discount them completely here without any negative info.   All in, this leads me to a no more than 20% probability.

While I have plenty of strong political opinions, as my friends and family will complain, I am going to try and look only at outside information to answer the question. Based on what I can find, Mueller will almost certainly not be done this year (see link) because special counsel investigations almost always take many years. More broadly about the special counsel role itself, the term and position have changed over time but there have been 10 up to and including Watergate and 18 since, not counting Mueller. I make the distinction because the 18 were appointed under a now lapsed independent council law that prohibited the president from firing them. Of the original 10, three were fired before they completed their work so my baseline here is 33% yes. Of those three two were fired after they went after the president directly (Grant and Henderson, Nixon and Cox) while the third was fired after he went comically overboard and started an investigation of the IRS by investigating every senior member of government (Truman and Morris). Of the other seven one was appointed by congress to investigate the Coolidge administration and he couldn't be fired and the other six were all appointed to investigate scandals in specific departments of the government like the post office or office of the navy. Of the special counsels that specifically investigated the president, all were actually fired, although typically the investigations didn't stop and someone else came in to finish the job. That being said, the president seems smart enough to have decided to hinder the investigation rather than fire Mueller. "A chart from Compass Point's Issac Boltansky and Lukas Davaz shows that the average length of special counsel investigations, dating back to Watergate, last on average 904 days...The longest such investigation was the investigation into President Bill Clinton's Whitewater real-estate deals. That investigation eventually morphed with the Monica Lewinsky scandal. It went on for 2,978 days...The investigation into the arms deals around the Iran-Contra affair under President Ronald Reagan lasted 2,420 days."[1] The number of days from May 17, 2017 to January 1, 2020 is 959 days.
